title: Krispy Kreme confesses to playing April Fools' Day prank two days early - but customers are not amused
text:
They took the joke quite far... (Photo: Krispy Cream) Share Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
Doughnut brand Krispy Kreme has today admitted its 'rebranding' in the UK was actually an April Fools' Day prank - even though they did it in March. 
Fair play, they managed to trick thousands of people on social media, although many insisted it must be a prank. 
What many people are asking, though, is why they ran an April Fools' Day prank two days early - on March 30. (You can scroll down for that explanation). 
Is nothing sacred anymore?! 
In case you missed it: Krispy Kreme announced yesterday that they are changing their name to 'Krispy Cream' in the UK because Brits have trouble saying it. 
But, alas, they're not. It was all a joke. The brand went as far as changing its logo and name on Twitter and its website - and bagging the www.krispyCream.co.uk domain to redirect to its site. 
In a statement to Mirror Online, a spokesperon said: "As you may have guessed by now, it was an April Foolâ€™s Day story and we will remain as Krispy Kreme within the UK. 
"The idea behind the story was to draw attention to the confusion around pronunciation and spelling of the brand in a humorous, irreverent way.
